title: ag.algebraic geometry - Sifted sets can't accumulate on a curve
body: Let $f,g,h$ be elements in $\mathbb{Z}[x,y]$ , each geometrically integral and at least two of them are distinct. Without loss of generality, suppose that $f$ is not proportional to $g$ over $\mathbb{C}$ , so that the variety $V_{f,g} = \{f = g = 0\}$ has co-dimension 2 in $\mathbb{A}^2$ . Let $T$ be a large real number, and fix a prime $T/\log T < p < T$ . Define the set $$\displaystyle S_{f,g}(T) = \{\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{Z}^2 \cap [-T,T]^2 : \mathbf{x} \pmod{\ell} \in V_{f,g}(\mathbb{F}_\ell) \text{ for some } T/\log T < \ell < T \},$$ where $\ell$ runs over primes. One can show that $$\displaystyle |S_{f,g}(T)| \asymp T.$$ My question is, is it possible for the intersection of $S_{f,g}(T)$ and the set $$\displaystyle C_h(p; T) = \{\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{Z}^2 \cap [-T,T]^2 : h(\mathbf{x}) \equiv 0 \pmod{p}\}$$ to be large? Indeed, the question is as in the title, can the "sifted set" $S_{f,g}(T)$ have large intersection with a curve modulo a fixed prime $p$ ? ag.algebraic-geometry nt.number-theory arithmetic-geometry Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jul 13, 2020 at 12:05 asked Jul 13, 2020 at 11:28 Stanley Yao Xiao ♦ 31k 7 7 gold badges 63 63 silver badges 173 173 bronze badges $\endgroup$ Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
